Versions.Question: State what is meant by a longitudinal traveling wave.
Versions.Answer: A longitudinal traveling wave is a wave in which the oscillations of the particles in the medium are parallel to the direction of energy transfer.

Versions.Question: For a longitudinal wave in this displacement-distance graph, identify centers of compression and rarefraction.
Versions.Answer:
Centre of rarefraction - F
Centers of compression - C,H

Versions.Question:
A longitudinal wave is traveling in a medium from left to right. The graph 
shows the variation with distance x of the displacement y of the particles in the 
medium. The solid line and the dotted line show the displacement at t = 0 and 
t = 0.882 ms, respectively. The period of the wave is greater than 0.882 ms. A 
displacement to the right of the equilibrium position is positive. 

The equilibrium position of a particle in the medium is at x = 0.80 m. For 
this particle at t = 0, state and explain the direction of motion
Versions.Answer:
The particle appears from the graph as though it is about to go ‘down’. However,
this is a longitudinal wave, and so the appropriate option is ‘left’, as this coincides
with the parallel particle oscillations and wave propagation. We know this because
its displacement is about to become negative.

Versions.Question: Define what is meant by the speed of a wave.
Versions.Answer: The speed of a wave is the distance traveled by the wave profile per unit time.

Versions.Question: Which graph shows the variation of amplitude with intensity for a wave?
Versions.Answer:
Intensity is proportional to the square of amplitude. Therefore, amplitude is proportional to
the square root of intensity.
Answer: A

Versions.Question: Define wavelength
Versions.Answer:
The distance between two consecutive crests or any two 
consecutive points that are in phase.

Versions.Question: Order of electromagnetic spectrum from lowest frequency to highest?
Versions.Answer: Radio waves, Microwaves, Infrared, Visible light, Ultraviolet, X-rays, and Gamma rays (Raging Martians Invaded Venus Using X-ray Guns)

Versions.Question: What is intensity of a wave, and what is its relationship with amplitude?
Versions.Answer: Power per unit area received by the observer, proportional to the square of its amplitude

Versions.Question:
Sound waves travel in air at room temperature at approximately 3.3 x 10^3 m/s whereas light, which is an electromagnetic wave, travels at 3.0 x 10^8 m/s.
Outline the nature of:
i. sound waves
ii. electromagnetic waves.
Versions.Answer: Sound waves are longitudinal mechanical waves that require a medium, propagating via particle compressions and rarefactions (e.g., air at ~343 m/s). Electromagnetic waves are transverse waves consisting of oscillating electric and magnetic fields, traveling at ~3.0 × 10⁸ m/s in vacuum without a medium.

Versions.Question: Discuss the similarities and differences between transverse and longitudinal waves.
Versions.Answer:
Similarities:
• Both transfer energy
• Exhibit reflection/refraction/diffraction/interference
• Follow v = fλ

Transverse Waves:
• Particle motion: ⟂ to wave direction
• Features: Crests & troughs
• Travel in vacuum (e.g., light, EM waves)
• Examples: Light, water waves

Longitudinal Waves:
• Particle motion: ∥ to wave direction
• Features: Compressions & rarefactions
• Require medium (e.g., sound in air)
• Examples: Sound, seismic P-waves

Versions.Question: Define wave
Versions.Answer: A disturbance that transfers energy from point to point in a medium

Versions.Question: Define frequency of a wave
Versions.Answer:
Frequency f is the number of oscillations per second formed by the wave
source. This is also the number of crests that pass a point in one second.

Versions.Question: Define time period of a wave
Versions.Answer:
Time period T is the time that it takes one wavelength to pass a fixed point.
This is the same as the time for one particle in the wave to undertake one
cycle of the oscillation

Versions.Question: Define amplitude of a wave
Versions.Answer:
Amplitude is the maximum displacement of a particle in the wave from its
equilibrium (rest) position.

Versions.Question: Define speed of a wave
Versions.Answer:
Wave speed is the distance a wave moves forward in one second in its
direction of propagation.

Versions.Question: Define the refractive index of a medium
Versions.Answer: It is the ratio of the speed of light in a vacuum to the speed of light in the medium

Versions.Question:
A ray oflight traveling in air is incident on a glass block at an angle of 56°. Calculate 
the angle of refraction if the refractive index of glass is 1.5.

What does each letter respresent in theequation
s = 𝜆𝐷 / 𝑑
Versions.Answer:
s = fringe spacing,	
𝜆 = wavelength,
D = distance between sources and screen,	
d = distance between sources

Versions.Question: What conditions must two wave sources meet to be considered coherent in interference experiments?
Versions.Answer:
Two sources are said to be coherent if they have the same frequency, similar
amplitude and a constant phase difference.

Versions.Question: Discuss the differences between traveling waves and standing waves
Versions.Answer:
Energy is propagated in traveling waves whereas it is stored in standing waves.
In a traveling wave every particle in the medium oscillates with the same amplitude, whereas in a standing wave particles oscillate with different amplitudes.

Versions.Question: Define coherent waves
Versions.Answer: waves with the same frequency and constant phase difference

Versions.Question: Define path difference
Versions.Answer: Amount of progress made by waves along a path, the difference in the distance travelled by the 2 waves

Versions.Question: Monochromatic means
Versions.Answer: having the same wavelength

Versions.Question: Define ray
Versions.Answer: A line that indicates the direction of energy propagation

Versions.Question: When light from two sources produces an observable interference pattern it is necessary that
Versions.Answer: The light emitted from the sources is in phase and has the same frequency
